results.title: The Thin Blue Line
results.brief_description: Errol Morris’s unique documentary dramatically re-enacts the crime scene and investigation of a police officer’s murder in Dallas in a film that the Criterion Collection describes as “a work of meticulous journalism and gripping drama”.

constellations_other.name: Reasonable doubt
constellations_other.description: Factual media has the power to reframe information and put forth new, persuasive arguments.  For the criminal justice system, where convictions are made based on arguments being convincing beyond a reasonable doubt, True Crime media has the ability to create doubt, right the wrongs of the justice system, and shed new light on closed cases.

constellations_other.name: Presumption of guilt
constellations_other.description: A Constellation looking at true crime documentaries, the nature of innocence and prejudice.

constellations_other.name: Reconstructing reality
constellations_other.description: While documentary pertains to be about the truth, many filmmakers and artists have used ingenious reconstructions to represent an abstracted honesty.

results.description: In this film Randall Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a police officer, swears that he did not commit the crime. In the way he dramatises the quest for evidence Morris emphasises the contradictions in the testimony of key witnesses and legal figures involved with the case and the inconclusiveness of the evidence which served to convict Adams, in what becomes an ironic reflection upon the nature of knowledge and truth. As Bill Nichols points out, Morris’s strategy is the converse of that of documentaries which subordinate their own textual voice to that of the witnesses. In the Thin Blue Line the textual voice actually threatens to overwhelm the discrete voices of the social actors (including that of Adams himself) with its own message about the problematics of representations.
description_for_label: In this film Randall Adams, serving a life sentence for the murder of a police officer, swears that he did not commit the crime. In the way he dramatises the quest for evidence Morris emphasises the contradictions in the testimony of key witnesses and legal figures involved with the case and the inconclusiveness of the evidence which served to convict Adams, in what becomes an ironic reflection upon the nature of knowledge and truth. As Bill Nichols points out, Morris’s strategy is the converse of that of documentaries which subordinate their own textual voice to that of the witnesses. In the Thin Blue Line the textual voice actually threatens to overwhelm the discrete voices of the social actors (including that of Adams himself) with its own message about the problematics of representations.

results.title: Tullamarine Project [B/W]
results.brief_description: A crowd waves goodbye to a TAA flight at Essendon Airport, aerial shots of the City of Melbourne and Yarra River. Late developmental stages of construction on the Tullamarine Airport and Freeway. Shot in October 1968.

results.title: Baltique Sea Plastique
results.brief_description: The Baltic Sea Plastique installation sets out to explore the complexity and controversial nature of the environmental threat caused by plastic waste.

constellations_other.name: Deep blue
constellations_other.description: Go deep on an exploration of real world oceans and those rendered by pixels and creatures made from plastics.

results.description: The word “plastic” derives from the Greek plastikos, meaning capable of being shaped or moulded (from plastos, “moulded”). It refers to the malleability or plasticity of the material.Plastic is a man-made material that has spread all over the world, and has led to so-called plastic pollution, which is almost impossible to clean up. The plasticity of plastics and their impact on the ecosystem are out of human control.The Baltic Sea Plastique installation sets out to explore the complexity and controversial nature of the environmental threat caused by plastic waste. The work combines the plasticity of visual arts with the creative and resilient capacity of marine life. The astonishing plastic beauty of marine creatures— all synthetic and made of plastic trash in the installation—evokes the formative process of nature. For better or for worse, plasticity is a testament to life’s metamorphic capability. Baltic Sea Plastique presents a plastic world of sensations in which synthetic and organic forms coexist, interact, and create puzzling natural artifacts. http://www.tuulanarhinen.net/artworks/baltplast.html

results.title: Awavena
results.material_description: AV equipment, installation materials, furnishings, rugs.
results.brief_description:
Awavena was made by Emmy and AACTA award-winning artist and director Lynette Wallworth, and screened to international acclaim at the 2018 Venice International Film Festival. It had its Melbourne debut at ACMI in 2019. The second in a series of VR works by Lynette Wallworth and producer Nicole Newnham (Collisions was the first and exhibited at ACMI in 2016), Awavena is a stunning tale of metamorphosis in the Brazilian Amazon.
For the Amazonian Yawanawa, “medicine” has the power to take you inside a vision to a place you have never been. By collaborating with artist Lynette Wallworth, Hushuhu, the first woman shaman of the Yawanawa is able to use VR like medicine to open a portal to another way of knowing. Awavena is a collaboration between a community and an artist, melding technology and transcendent experience so that a vision can be shared, and a story told of a people ascending from the edge of extinction.
Wallworth was invited by the Yawanawa to create this stunning VR experience using cutting edge technology to mirror their vision states. Awavena was an unmissable experience and a gift from the Yawanawa that they hoped would shift our consciousness and change the way we perceived the world and the decisions we make.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.title: [Albert Drayton Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
This film follows on from the Drayton Family Movies: Reel 5

The film continues exploring events and scenes from Raboul in Papua New Guinea then continues to other villages.

There are many scenes of local people in costume providing performances and ceremonies for the tourists of the cruise ship.

There are a few scenes of missionary buildings and schools and many scenes of students in uniform. The student marching teams are seen doing regimented marching exercises.

Also seen are ruins and gravestones from early missionaries on the island.

Towards the end of the film a duk-duk dance is filmed. At the time it was an illegal dance to perform.

The film finishes at the arrival of another village in New Britain.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 – Young Chinese students, at the Overseas Chinese School, Raboul

00:00:09:00 – Harold Drayton, Mr Jefferies, Albert Drayton standing in a church doorway, Raboul

00:00:29:00 – Local Cemetery holding Australians soldiers killed in the First World War, Raboul

00:01:12:00 – Guards on Duty, Government House, Raboul

00:01:41:00 – Prisoners marching back to their cells after a day’s work, Raboul

00:01:51:00 – local costume and dance performance. George Brown College, Raboul

00:02:57:00 – College Boys in uniform marching, Raboul

00:03:22:00 – Harold Drayton, Mrs Drayton, Mr Drayton, Mrs Lowe, Mrs Hargraves part of the Sunshine cruise passengers drinking from coconuts

00:03:56:00 – Dance Performances and music, St George Browns College, Raboul

00:07:03:00 – George Brown College boys and girls, performing marching exercises, rhythm exercises with coconut shells and sticks, Raboul

00:09:40:00 – Passengers of the cruise on a hike with sun umbrellas, Raboul

00:09:56:00 – Man sitting on Tortoise as it tries to move, Raboul

00:11:12:00 – Cruise passengers posing with local men

00:11:14:00 – local man with spear and Axe

00:11:53:00 – local man performs a banned Duk-Duk-dance

00:13:45:00 – Farewelled by village locals, New Britain, boats point of view

00:14:26:00 – Arriving at a new village (unidentified) New Britain with local students in uniform and drums being played to welcome the tourists

results.title: The Thief of Baghdad
results.creator_credit: Raoul Walsh, Douglas Fairbanks and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. He tries to win the heart of his true love, the Caliph’s daughter, by competing with various Princes to find rare treasure.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Raoul Walsh, Douglas Fairbanks and United Artists Corporation
results.description: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. He tries to win the heart of his true love, the Caliph’s daughter, by competing with various Princes to find rare treasure. He climbs clouds, battles sea-creatures and killer plants, defeats the Mongols with an army of dust, rides a winged horse and finally becomes victorious. This silent classic is a much loved children’s film.
description_for_label: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. This silent classic is a much loved children’s film.

results.title: The Soundmaker (2004)
results.material_description:
3-channel film installation
Colour, sound
Loop, 35 min 7 sec
While the action takes place on the central screen, two screens at the sides show the procedure of sound-making.
results.brief_description: The Soundmaker (2004) is the first part of Rosefeldt’s Trilogy of Failure (2004/2005) in which three different settings draw a picture of our vain entanglement with everyday rituals.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description:
The Soundmaker (2004) is the first part of Rosefeldt’s Trilogy of Failure (2004/2005) in which three different settings draw a picture of our vain entanglement with everyday rituals. In each case the protagonist is caught up in a microcosm that suggests mental and spatial claustrophobia. As a reaction to the hopeless situation, he plunges into permanent Sisyphean activity – going nowhere and producing nothing. The motifs of perpetual attempt and constant failure find their equivalent in the repetitive structure of the loop. The scenes are allegories of our frantic and ultimately futile attempts to escape the surrounding norms, constraints, structures and rituals by which we are determined.

The Soundmaker piles, in endless iteration, the furnishings of his room into his own personal Tower of Babel, only to dismantle it and return the room to its original state again. His performance is accompanied by a Foley artist, an alter ego looking identical to himself. While the action takes place on the central screen, two screens at the sides show the procedure of sound-making. Shot in aerial and frontal perspective, the screens depict the translation from life as it occurs in the centre into simple objects and minimal movements. As in many of his latter projects, Rosefeldt reflects upon the myth machinery of cinema by showing the film set behind the scenes, while simultaneously using it as a metaphor for the mechanics of life.

Summarised from Stefan Berg and Katerina Gregos, in: Julian Rosefeldt: Film Works (2008).

  • https://www.julianrosefeldt.com/

results.title: Turbulent
results.brief_description: Turbulent is a two-screen film installation by famous Iranian artist Shirin Neshat. It is among her most critically acclaimed works, having won her a Lion d’Or at the Venice Biennale back in 1999.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.description: Two-channel video installation. A man performs and is applauded on one screen. On the second screen a woman begins to sing disrupting and challenging the male space.
description_for_label: Two-channel video installation. A man performs and is applauded on one screen. On the second screen a woman begins to sing disrupting and challenging the male space.

images.credit_line: Shirin Neshat – Turbulent, 1998, black-and-white video installation, installation view, Lahore Biennale, 2018, photo: Usman Saqib Zuberi/lahorebiennale.org
images.alt_text: An installation view of a screen-based artwork that features a black and white image of a bearded man, with people seated in a purple room watching it
